heroDescription: Naval Shipbuilding • A$2.5B Mkt Cap • A$13.1B Order Book
heroCompanyDescription: Austal Limited (ASX: ASB) is Australia's largest defence shipbuilder, operating shipyards in Henderson (WA), Mobile (Alabama), and National Steel & Shipbuilding Company (NASSCO). The company builds aluminium combat ships and steel vessels for the US Navy, Australian Defence Force, and international customers. In 1HFY26 (reported 17 February 2026), Austal delivered EPS of A$0.16 — a 99% beat on consensus of A$0.08 — and held an order book of A$13.1B. However, guidance was cut from A$135M to A$110M EBIT for FY26 following the discovery of a US$17.1M accounting error in the T-ATS program.

skew.rationale: The A$13.1B order book provides multi-year revenue visibility, and global defence spending is structurally elevated. The 1HFY26 earnings beat (+99% vs consensus) is a genuine positive. However, the US$17.1M T-ATS accounting error and resulting guidance downgrade introduce uncertainty about internal controls. The order book de-risks the revenue line; the question is margin delivery.

verdict.text: Austal's 1HFY26 result (17 February 2026) was a double-edged outcome: EPS of A$0.16 beat consensus by 99%, and the order book grew to A$13.1B — but EBIT guidance was cut from A$135M to A$110M for FY26 due to a US$17.1M accounting error (double-counted T-ATS program incentives). The stock surged 20% on the day then recovered to A$6.22. At 26.7x trailing P/E with no dividend, the valuation reflects the defence spending super-cycle and AUKUS opportunity rather than current earnings. The order book covers approximately 15 years of revenue at current run-rates, making near-term contract wins less important than margin execution.

featuredRationale: Record order book A$13.1B with AUKUS and US Navy tailwinds, but accounting error exposed internal control risk and cut FY26 guidance 18.5% from A$135M to A$110M.

identity.overview: Austal Limited is Australia's premier defence shipbuilder and one of the world's leading naval vessel constructors. The company builds aluminium high-speed craft (Independence-class Littoral Combat Ships, Expeditionary Fast Transports, and patrol boats) and steel vessels (via NASSCO) for the US Navy, US Coast Guard, and Australian Defence Force. The A$13.1B order book as of 1HFY26 represents multi-year revenue visibility across three shipyards. The AUKUS agreement (Australia-UK-US nuclear submarine partnership) and Australia's 2024 Defence Strategic Review have created a structural tailwind for domestic shipbuilding capacity, with Austal positioning itself as a key beneficiary. However, a US$17.1M accounting error discovered in the T-ATS program — where program incentives were double-counted — resulted in an FY26 EBIT guidance downgrade from A$135M to A$110M, raising internal control questions.

hypotheses.title: D1: US Defence Contract Pipeline Secures Multi-Year Revenue
hypotheses.description: The US Department of Defense continues to award Austal new contracts across its Mobile and NASSCO facilities. The A$13.1B order book converts to revenue and earnings at contracted margins, and new contract wins (US Navy logistics vessels, TAGOS-23 ocean surveillance ships, additional Expeditionary Fast Transports) expand the pipeline. Austal is effectively a captive supplier in specific US Navy aluminium vessel categories.
requires: US Congress passes the FY26 and FY27 National Defense Authorization Act with full Austal-relevant vessel funding
Austal Mobile and NASSCO maintain on-time/on-budget delivery performance above 85%
No major programme cancellations in the Independence-class or EPF programmes
New TAGOS-23 contract (ocean surveillance) awarded to Austal Mobile shipyard
US Navy shipbuilding budget not materially cut in annual appropriations
supporting: Filings: Order book of A$13.1B as of 1HFY26 — approximately 15x FY25 annual revenue, providing 12-15 years of work at current delivery rates
Corporate: CEO Paddy Gregg confirmed the T1 pipeline conversion from 1HFY26 results — no major contract cancellations disclosed
Competitor: Austal is the sole aluminium naval shipbuilder in the US, with Ingalls (HII) and Marinette Marine focused on steel vessels — effectively a monopoly in its niche
Economic: US defence spending approved at approximately US$886B for FY2026 — above pre-NDAA estimates; shipbuilding a priority line item
Filings: TAGOS-23 programme (up to 20 vessels) is in late-stage competitive evaluation with Austal as the front-runner given Mobile yard capacity
contradicting: Filings: US$17.1M T-ATS accounting error suggests contract margin visibility may not be as clear as previously represented
Economic: US federal budget deficit concerns could pressure DoD discretionary spending in FY27-FY28 under a deficit-reduction agenda
Competitor: Huntington Ingalls Industries (HII) has a stronger balance sheet and could bid for vessel types traditionally held by Austal
Corporate: Fixed-price contracts mean cost overruns directly erode EBIT — NASSCO has had historical execution challenges

hypotheses.title: D2: AUKUS / Australian Defence Uplift Creates Domestic Pipeline
hypotheses.description: The AUKUS agreement commits Australia to acquiring nuclear-powered submarines and massively expanding domestic naval shipbuilding capacity. Austal's Henderson shipyard (WA) is the designated facility for new Australian patrol vessels, minor war combatants, and potentially supporting the nuclear submarine programme. As the ADF expands its surface fleet, Austal captures a disproportionate share of Australian naval work.
requires: Australian Defence Capability Plan (ADCP) allocates surface combatant work to Austal Henderson
AUKUS Pillar II (non-nuclear technology sharing) programmes create Austal-relevant contract opportunities
Australian government commits to sustainment contracts for existing vessels at Henderson
New patrol vessel or minor war combatant contract awarded to Henderson shipyard FY26-FY28
AUKUS nuclear submarine pathway does not divert all Australian defence funding away from surface fleet
supporting: Economic: Australia's Defence budget increasing from 2.0% to 2.4% of GDP by 2030 — adds approximately A$5B/year in new spending
Corporate: Austal Henderson has been invested in to support future AUKUS-related maintenance and sustainment work
Competitor: Luerssen (the other major Australian defence shipbuilder) focuses on offshore patrol vessels; Austal has no competition in aluminium fast vessel category
Economic: 2024 Australian Defence Strategic Review explicitly named sovereign shipbuilding capability as a national security priority
contradicting: Economic: The nuclear submarine programme (AUKUS Pillar I) will absorb a disproportionate share of the expanded defence budget — surface fleet funding remains constrained
Regulatory: Australian government procurement timelines are notoriously slow; AUKUS-related domestic work may not materialise in commercially significant volumes until FY28-FY30
Filings: Henderson shipyard revenue is a small fraction of the A$13.1B order book; the domestic AUKUS thesis is a future option, not a current earnings driver
Competitor: BAE Systems (Australia) and Luerssen have also been positioning aggressively for Australian naval contract awards

hypotheses.title: D3: US Revenue Gap Creates Earnings Cliff
hypotheses.description: As the Independence-class Littoral Combat Ship programme winds down and the EPF programme approaches completion, Austal faces a revenue gap between existing US contracts rolling off and new contracts ramping up. If the TAGOS-23 or other new programmes are delayed or awarded to competitors, the Mobile and NASSCO facilities face underutilisation in FY27-FY28, creating an earnings cliff.
requires: TAGOS-23 contract is not awarded to Austal, or is significantly delayed past FY27
US Congress delays or reduces EPF and LCS follow-on funding
No new major programme awards to Austal Mobile or NASSCO shipyards in FY26
Fixed costs at US facilities cannot be reduced proportionally with revenue decline
Henderson does not receive sufficient domestic work to offset US revenue gap
supporting: Corporate: The LCS programme (Independence-class) has been the subject of DoD programme reviews and vessel count reductions since 2021
Economic: US shipbuilding programme transitions always carry timing risk — gaps between programmes are common in the US naval procurement cycle
Filings: NASSCO has had execution challenges historically; steel vessel building is a different capability to Austal's aluminium heritage
Competitor: HII (Ingalls) has been lobbying to take aluminium vessel work back in-house, which could threaten future contract awards
contradicting: Filings: Order book of A$13.1B covers 15+ years at current delivery rates — revenue cliff is not near-term
Corporate: TAGOS-23 programme is progressing; Austal has been shortlisted and the yard has the capacity
Economic: US Navy shipbuilding budget has been a priority for both the Trump and Biden administrations — bipartisan support
Competitor: As the US's only aluminium naval shipbuilder, Austal has no direct competition for its specific vessel types

hypotheses.title: D4: Fixed-Price Contracts Recur with Cost Overruns + Governance
hypotheses.description: Austal's US operations have a history of fixed-price contract cost overruns and programme delivery challenges. The discovery of the US$17.1M T-ATS accounting error — where program incentives were double-counted — reveals internal control weaknesses. If further accounting issues or cost overruns emerge across the NASSCO or Mobile programmes, market confidence in management credibility collapses and the stock de-rates materially.
requires: Additional accounting errors or restatements discovered beyond the T-ATS programme
NASSCO or Mobile programme cost overruns exceed contract provisions in FY26 or FY27
US DoD deems Austal non-compliant with contract performance requirements
DCAA (Defense Contract Audit Agency) initiates formal audit process
Management guidance proves unreliable for a second consecutive period
supporting: Filings: US$17.1M T-ATS accounting error (double-counted incentives) cut FY26 EBIT guidance 18.5% from A$135M to A$110M — material and embarrassing
Filings: Austal's US operations have had fixed-price contract cost overrun issues previously (LCS programme in 2017-2019, NASSCO transitions)
Academic: Fixed-price defence contracts are structurally risky for shipbuilders; cost overruns cannot be passed to the customer and directly erode EBIT
Corporate: The T-ATS error was described as an isolated incident — but isolated incidents that result in 18.5% guidance cuts damage management credibility
contradicting: Corporate: Management described the T-ATS error as a specific double-counting of incentive milestones — not a systemic accounting control failure
Filings: The A$13.1B order book is audited and contract-backed — order book integrity is not in question
Competitor: All US defence contractors operating on fixed-price contracts face similar execution risk; it is systemic to the sector, not Austal-specific
Economic: US DoD has historically worked with Austal to restructure challenged programmes rather than terminate — relationship continuity mitigates T4

narrative.theNarrative: Austal is operating in the sweet spot of the global defence spending super-cycle: a A$13.1B order book, a near-monopoly in US aluminium naval shipbuilding, and the AUKUS tailwind for Australian domestic work. The 1HFY26 result (17 February 2026) delivered a massive earnings beat — EPS A$0.16 vs A$0.08 consensus — and the stock surged 20%. But the guidance cut tells a more complex story. The US$17.1M T-ATS accounting error that cut FY26 EBIT guidance from A$135M to A$110M introduces a question that the market is not yet fully pricing: is this an isolated error or a symptom of systemic control issues? The bull case rests on order book conversion and programme wins. The bear case asks whether the earnings quality is as strong as the headline beat implies.

priceImplication.label: Embedded Assumptions at A$6.22
priceImplication.content: Order book converts at margin: A$13.1B converts without material further cost overruns. T-ATS is isolated: Market assumes the accounting error is one-off, not systemic. TAGOS-23 awarded to Austal: Mobile yard needs the programme to sustain US revenue beyond current backlog. AUKUS optionality priced in: Australian domestic shipbuilding acceleration is a long-dated option embedded in the price. Guidance credibility restored: FY26 A$110M EBIT is achievable — no further downgrades.

narrative.evidenceCheck: The order book evidence (A$13.1B) is genuinely exceptional and de-risks the revenue line materially. The 1HFY26 EPS beat is real and reflects improved programme execution and milestone billing. However, the T-ATS accounting error is the most important piece of evidence for bear thesis evaluation: when a company discloses that it double-counted US$17.1M of incentives on a single programme, the natural question is whether similar issues exist elsewhere in the backlog. Management said no. The market largely accepted that. But it is unverifiable without a formal internal audit. The order book quality — not quantity — is the key uncertainty.
narrative.narrativeStability: Conditionally stable, with elevated tail risk. The narrative is stable as long as: (1) FY26 EBIT guidance of A$110M is delivered; (2) no further accounting restatements; (3) TAGOS-23 progresses. The narrative would become unstable if: any of the above fails, or if a second accounting issue emerges (which would confirm T4 as systemic rather than isolated). Given that the stock nearly doubled from its 52-week low (A$3.50 to A$6.22), the market has already repriced the AUKUS and order book narrative — the marginal catalyst needed is execution confirmation.

evidence.intro: Ten evidence domains assessed across Austal's 1HFY26 results, defence contract pipeline, AUKUS context, and accounting governance risk. The order book evidence is compelling; the T-ATS accounting error is the key risk variable.

cards.title: 1. Corporate Communications
cards.finding: Austal's 1HFY26 results presentation (17 February 2026) had a dual character. Positives: EPS A$0.16 (+99% vs consensus), order book A$13.1B, strong programme execution commentary, and confidence in US Navy pipeline. Critical negative: Management disclosed that FY26 EBIT guidance was being cut from A$135M to A$110M due to the T-ATS (Training Ship) programme where US$17.1M of incentives had been double-counted in prior period revenue recognition. CEO Paddy Gregg characterised the error as an isolated accounting matter affecting a single programme, and stated that a comprehensive review of all programmes had been completed with no further issues identified. Management expressed confidence in the A$110M EBIT guidance and the order book quality.
cards.tension: The tension is between management's assertion that the T-ATS error is isolated and the market's inability to independently verify this. A US$17.1M double-counting on a single programme is a material accounting error; management's reassurance, while necessary, is also motivated. The comprehensive programme review management referenced has not been independently audited.
cards.source: Austal 1HFY26 Results; ASX Release 17 February 2026; Investor Presentation

cards.title: 2. Regulatory Filings & Financial Statements
cards.finding: 1HFY26 key financials: EPS A$0.16 (H1 FY25: approximately A$0.08), EBIT approximately A$65-70M (run-rate implies FY26 A$110M EBIT guidance achievable). Order book A$13.1B confirmed in statutory disclosures. The T-ATS restatement: The prior period revenue recognition for T-ATS programme incentives was overstated by US$17.1M. This required an FY26 EBIT guidance revision. The error was identified through an internal programme review, not an external audit finding — which is slightly reassuring (internal controls caught it) but also concerning (it was not caught earlier). No dividend declared. Henderson WA and US operations both contributed to the 1H result.
cards.tension: The statutory accounts confirm the magnitude of the T-ATS error. A US$17.1M programme accounting error on a company with A$110M full-year EBIT guidance represents approximately 15% of annual profitability — highly material. The internal audit review described as 'complete with no further issues found' has not been independently verified.

tags.text: Partially Supports T4 (T-ATS error scale material)
Contradicts T3 (order book robust — no near-term cliff)

cards.source: Austal 1HFY26 Half-Year Report; ASX 17 February 2026; ASIC filings

cards.title: 3. Broker Research
cards.finding: Post-results broker response was mixed-positive. The 1HFY26 EPS beat drove upgrades from most covering analysts. Approximately 4 of 6 analysts have Buy or Equivalent ratings; 2 have Hold. Average 12-month price target post-results is approximately A$7.00-7.50, implying ~12-20% upside from A$6.22. Bull case brokers (UBS, Bell Potter) focused on the order book quality, AUKUS optionality, and the EPS beat. Neutral brokers flagged the T-ATS accounting error as a credibility issue and noted that the guidance cut offsets the operational beat. Key debate: Is the A$110M FY26 EBIT guidance achievable given the T-ATS history, and what is the sustainable EBIT margin for Austal's US operations?
cards.tension: The dispersion in analyst views (target range A$6.50-A$8.00+) reflects genuine uncertainty about the normalised earnings power and the timing of AUKUS-related domestic revenue. The accounting error has made margin forecasting materially harder.

tags.text: Neutral on T4 (accounting credibility concern noted but not dominant)

cards.source: UBS Equities; Bell Potter Securities; Macquarie Research; consensus data February 2026

cards.title: 4. Competitor & Industry Data
cards.finding: Austal occupies a near-monopoly position in US aluminium naval shipbuilding. Key US naval shipbuilders: Huntington Ingalls Industries (HII) builds aircraft carriers, destroyers, and nuclear submarines (no direct competition with Austal in aluminium vessels). Fincantieri (Italian) has been discussed as a potential bidder for some US programmes, but political and Buy American considerations significantly limit foreign competition. Marinette Marine (Fincantieri subsidiary) builds the Freedom-class LCS (Austal's steel competitor). TAGOS-23 competition: Austal Mobile vs potentially Senesco Marine (smaller yard) — Austal is widely considered the frontrunner. Global defence shipbuilding market: Order backlogs across all major naval shipbuilders are at multi-decade highs; Korean (HD Hyundai, HHI) and Japanese shipbuilders are also capacity-constrained.

tags.text: Supports T2 (global capacity constrained — AUKUS work needs Austal)
Contradicts T3 (no credible substitute for aluminium US naval work)

cards.source: HII annual report; US Navy shipbuilding budget; Defense News; NASSCO programme disclosures

cards.title: 5. Economic Data
cards.finding: Global defence spending at multi-decade highs. NATO members are increasing defence budgets toward the 2% GDP target; Australia committed to 2.4% of GDP by 2030. The US FY2026 NDAA (National Defense Authorization Act) authorised approximately US$886B in defence spending, with naval shipbuilding a priority. AUKUS financial commitment: Australia committed A$368B (present value) over the AUKUS programme lifetime for submarines and associated capability uplift — the largest single defence commitment in Australian history. While most is submarine-focused, the associated industrial capacity development benefits Austal Henderson. Exchange rate: ASB reports in AUD but earns significant USD revenue; the AUD has weakened modestly in 2025-2026, providing a translation tailwind for USD-denominated US contract earnings.
cards.tension: The US federal deficit and a Trump administration focus on government efficiency (DOGE) could create headwinds for discretionary defence spending growth in FY27-FY28, even if the bipartisan consensus on China threat supports the overall defence budget.

tags.text: Strongly Supports T1 (US defence budget robust)
Mild concern for T3 (budget deficit could constrain FY27-FY28 growth)

cards.source: US FY2026 NDAA; Australian 2024 Defence Strategic Review; Australian Budget MYEFO; ABS exchange rate data

cards.title: 6. Alternative Data
cards.finding: US Navy procurement signals are positive. The US Navy's 30-year shipbuilding plan (released with the FY2026 budget) maintains Austal-relevant vessel types at current or higher procurement rates. The TAGOS-23 programme Request for Proposal (RFP) has been released and Austal Mobile submitted a compliant bid. Congressional indicators: Both Republican and Democrat senators from Alabama have publicly supported the Mobile shipyard's US Navy work — bipartisan political support. Defence contractor sentiment: HII and L3Harris have noted elevated US naval capacity constraints, indirectly supporting Austal's pricing power. Australian defence industry signals: The Naval Shipbuilding College (Henderson WA) and Austal's apprenticeship programme indicate the company is investing in domestic workforce capacity for future AUKUS work.
cards.tension: Alternative data is uniformly positive but limited in transparency. DoD contract award information has publication delays that make real-time assessment difficult.
cards.source: US Navy 30-Year Shipbuilding Plan; TAGOS-23 RFP; Congressional Record; Austal corporate presentations

cards.title: 7. Academic Research
cards.finding: Defence contractor literature on fixed-price risk is relevant. Published research on US defence contracting demonstrates: (1) fixed-price contracts significantly increase earnings volatility for shipbuilders relative to cost-plus contracts; (2) programme transitions (end of one vessel type, beginning of another) are the highest-risk periods for earnings cliffs; (3) single-customer concentration (US Navy represents >60% of Austal revenue) creates contract risk that is hard to diversify. Naval procurement research: US Navy shipbuilding has been chronically underfunded relative to the 355-ship goal since 2015, creating a structural backlog that supports demand for all qualified shipbuilders. Accounting quality research: Programme-based revenue recognition (percentage-of-completion) is inherently susceptible to estimate errors — the T-ATS error is a known archetype in defence contractor accounting.

tags.text: Supports T4 (fixed-price earnings volatility; percentage-completion risk)
Contradicts T3 (structural US Navy backlog de-risks cliff)

cards.source: Journal of Defense Analysis; Acquisition Research Program (NPS); GAO shipbuilding reports; accounting quality literature

cards.title: 8. Media & Social
cards.finding: Media coverage of 1HFY26 results was largely positive on the earnings beat, with caveats. AFR covered the 20% surge on results day as a validation of the AUKUS investment thesis and the defence spending super-cycle. The T-ATS accounting error received less coverage than the earnings beat — investors focused on the headline EPS figure. Social media sentiment on Austal is limited (not a retail-heavy stock). Key themes in financial media: AUKUS opportunity, order book quality, and the defence sector de-rating reversal (ASB had fallen from A$8.82 52-week high to A$3.50 before the recovery). The accounting error was characterised as a technical accounting adjustment rather than a fundamental concern in most media coverage.
cards.tension: The media narrative may have over-discounted the T-ATS governance signal. A US$17.1M accounting error on a company earning A$110M EBIT is material; the media focus on the EPS beat may have shifted attention away from the more important question of internal control quality.

tags.text: Supports T1 (AUKUS narrative dominant in media)

cards.source: AFR 17-18 February 2026; The Australian; Bloomberg defence coverage

cards.title: 9. Leadership & Governance
cards.finding: CEO Paddy Gregg (appointed 2022) has stabilised the business after years of US operations challenges. The Henderson WA and NASSCO yards have shown improved programme management under his tenure. However, the T-ATS accounting error — identified internally but not caught until it required a guidance revision — raises questions about the effectiveness of the financial controls review process. Key governance concern: Percentage-of-completion accounting (the revenue recognition method for long-term contracts) is the most judgment-intensive accounting method; errors in incentive milestone recognition are a known failure mode. The fact that the error was found internally is somewhat reassuring, but the fact it was found only after impacting reported results is concerning.
cards.tension: Paddy Gregg has a credibility problem to manage: the market gave him the benefit of the doubt on the 1HFY26 EPS beat, but the guidance cut means the full-year bar is lower. Delivering A$110M EBIT in FY26 will partially restore credibility; any further downside surprise would be severely punished.

rows: Inherited US operations challenges; now managing T-ATS credibility
Overseeing accounting review and controls improvement post-T-ATS
Retained ~15% stake; alignment with long-term business health

tags.text: Supports T4 (T-ATS error raises control questions)

cards.source: Austal Annual Report; ASX Director Disclosures; AFR executive profiles

cards.title: 10. Ownership & Capital Flows
cards.finding: John Rothwell (founder) retains approximately 15% of Austal, providing strong insider alignment. Institutional ownership is building as the AUKUS narrative has attracted defence-specialist funds. The stock's recovery from A$3.50 to A$6.22 reflects significant institutional re-rating rather than retail buying. Short interest: Elevated short position pre-results (approximately 5-7% of free float) has been partially covered on the results beat, which amplified the 20% price surge (short covering + fundamental buying). Post-results, short interest is estimated to have reduced to approximately 3-4%. Capital structure: No dividend; free cash flow is being reinvested in shipyard capacity. No significant buyback programme.

tags.text: Supports T1 (founder alignment — no distribution pressure)

cards.source: ASX substantial holder notices; ASIC short position reports; Austal Annual Report

discriminators.intro: Three high-diagnosticity events will resolve the key competing hypotheses for Austal. TAGOS-23 contract award, FY26 full-year result, and any further accounting disclosures are the defining data points.

rows.evidence: TAGOS-23 programme contract award (expected late 2026). Austal Mobile is the leading bidder. Award confirms T1 and secures US revenue through 2030+.
rows.discriminatesBetween: T1 (US pipeline secured) vs T3 (US revenue gap emerging as LCS winds down)

rows.evidence: FY26 full-year EBIT result vs A$110M guidance. Delivery of A$110M confirms management credibility post-T-ATS. Material miss triggers T4 re-evaluation.
rows.discriminatesBetween: T4 (controls/overruns systemic) vs T1 (T-ATS was isolated and earnings quality is intact)
rows.currentReading: H1 tracking implied A$110M full-year — monitoring

rows.evidence: Any further accounting disclosures or DoD audit findings. A second T-ATS-style restatement would confirm T4 as systemic.
rows.discriminatesBetween: T4 (systemic governance failure) vs T1/T2 (T-ATS isolated; business fundamentally sound)
rows.currentReading: Management: review complete, no further issues — unverified

rows.evidence: Australian Defence ADCP surface fleet contract announcements. Henderson WA allocation confirms T2 (AUKUS domestic pipeline).
rows.discriminatesBetween: T2 (AUKUS creates domestic pipeline) vs T2 failing (all funding absorbed by submarines)

discriminators.nonDiscriminating: "Australia is increasing defence spending" (priced in at 26.7x P/E) • "Austal has a big order book" (A$13.1B is known and confirmed) • "AUKUS is good for Austal" (structural thesis widely understood) • "T-ATS was an isolated error" (management assertion — not independently verifiable, not discriminating without further data)

tripwires.intro: Three revision conditions. TAGOS-23 outcome and FY26 EBIT delivery are the defining near-term events. Any further accounting disclosure would be the most severe negative trigger.

cards.name: TAGOS-23 Contract Award

conditions.if: If Austal Mobile awarded TAGOS-23 contract (up to 20 vessels)
conditions.then: T1 strongly confirmed. Mobile yard revenue secured through 2032+. T3 (revenue cliff) eliminated for the next 5 years. Stock likely re-rates toward A$7.50-8.00.

conditions.if: If TAGOS-23 is awarded to a competitor or programme is cancelled
conditions.then: T3 activated. Mobile yard faces material underutilisation from FY27. Revenue gap narrative dominates. Stock likely de-rates toward A$5.00-5.50.

cards.source: Source: US Navy programme documentation; Defense News; ASX Austal contract announcements

cards.name: FY26 Full-Year Result vs A$110M EBIT

conditions.if: If FY26 EBIT is delivered at or above A$110M with no further accounting adjustments
conditions.then: Management credibility restored. T4 recedes. T1 and T2 narratives strengthen. Stock may re-rate toward A$7.00+.

conditions.if: If FY26 EBIT is below A$100M or requires further restatement
conditions.then: T4 elevated sharply. Internal control questions become central investment concern. Stock likely de-rates 20-30%. Management credibility severely damaged.

cards.source: Source: Austal FY26 Full-Year Results; ASX Announcement August 2026

cards.name: Further Accounting Disclosures / DoD Audit

conditions.if: If no further accounting errors or DoD audit issues in FY26
conditions.then: T4 recedes materially. T-ATS confirmed as isolated. Bull narrative regains full credibility.

conditions.if: If a second accounting error or adverse DoD DCAA audit finding is disclosed
conditions.then: T4 becomes the dominant thesis. Market severely punishes repeat control failures in listed defence companies. De-rating of 30-40% possible.

cards.source: Source: ASX Austal disclosures; US DCAA audit records; DoD Inspector General reports

couldntAssess: Programme-level margin detail: Individual programme margins within the A$13.1B order book are not disclosed. Whether the T-ATS double-counting represents a one-off error or a pattern across other programmes cannot be determined from public data.

DCAA audit status: The US Defence Contract Audit Agency's current audit position on Austal's US contracts is not publicly disclosed. An adverse DCAA finding would be the most severe negative trigger for T4.
TAGOS-23 bid details: The specifics of Austal's TAGOS-23 bid (price, terms, delivery schedule) are confidential. Whether the bid is commercially attractive or simply competitive on price is unknown.
AUKUS surface work allocation: The specific work packages allocated to Austal Henderson from the Australian Defence Capability Plan surface fleet review are not yet publicly disclosed.
gaps.analyticalLimitations: Hypothesis survival scores (T1: 45%, T2: 30%, T3: 35%, T4: 20%) reflect current evidence. T1 scores highest due to the scale and strategic value of the order book. T3 is elevated because the programme transition from LCS to new vessel types creates near-term revenue gap risk. T4 scores 20% — higher than might be expected for a mature defence contractor — specifically because of the T-ATS accounting error. The T4 score would reduce materially if FY26 EBIT is delivered in full and no further accounting issues emerge.

trend.structure: Sharp V-shaped recovery from 52-week low A$3.50 in August 2025. Stock surged 20% on 17 February 2026 results day. Now 78% above the low but 30% below the 52-week high of A$8.82.

support.method: Pre-results high; previous resistance now support

priorSpikes.context: 52-week low; US contract concerns and guidance fears
Results day: 20% surge on EPS +99% beat

inflectionPoints.event: 52-week low; US DoD programme review concerns
1HFY26 results: EPS +99%, order book A$13.1B; +20% surge

footer.disclaimer: This report does not constitute personal financial advice. Continuum Intelligence synthesises cross-domain evidence using the Analysis of Competing Hypotheses (ACH) methodology. All factual claims are sourced from ASX filings, company accounts, broker consensus data, and publicly available information. This report does not contain buy, sell, or hold recommendations, price targets, or valuation models.
